criticalSuccess: Your body moves through the water with practiced efficiency. Each stroke is powerful and precise, your breathing perfectly timed. Your legs kick with strong rhythm while your arms pull through the water, propelling you forward at impressive speed. You swim like someone born to the water!

You attack the water with athletic grace. Your streamlined form cuts through the waves with minimal resistance, and your powerful strokes eat up the distance. This is swimming at its finest - strong, smooth, and swift!
With each pull of your arms, you surge forward through the water. Your technique is superb, wasting no energy on unnecessary movement. You glide through the water like a predator, fast and confident!
success: You swim with solid technique, arms and legs working together to push you through the water. It's not effortless, but you're making good forward progress with each stroke.
You propel yourself through the water with determined effort. Your swimming is functional and effective, if not spectacular. You're covering distance steadily.
Your strokes carry you forward adequately. The water provides resistance, but you have the strength and skill to overcome it. You're swimming successfully.
failure: Despite your best efforts, you can't seem to make any forward progress. You're treading water effectively enough, but your attempts to swim ahead are fruitless. The water seems to resist every stroke.
You struggle against the water, arms and legs churning, but you're essentially staying in one place. Your technique isn't working, and you're expending energy without gaining ground.
Try as you might, you can't get your swimming to work. You stay afloat, but forward movement eludes you completely. The water has won this round.
criticalFailure: Your arms suddenly feel like lead. Your legs stop responding properly. Panic flashes through you as you realize you're no longer staying up - you're going down. Water closes over your head as you sink beneath the surface, lungs burning!
Your technique fails catastrophically. One moment you're trying to swim, the next your head is under water. You thrash desperately, but you can't seem to get back to the surface. You're drowning!
Exhaustion or fear takes over, and your swimming simply stops working. Your body sinks like a stone. Water floods into your mouth and nose as you slip under, the surface retreating above you!

criticalSuccess: You become one with the water, your body transformed into a vessel of pure aquatic efficiency. Each stroke is poetry in motion - arms slicing through the surface with barely a splash, legs driving you forward with metronomic precision. Your breathing is perfectly controlled, never breaking your rhythm. You don't fight the water - you use it, working with the current, reading the waves, finding the path of least resistance. The distance melts away beneath your mastery. You swim with the confidence and skill of someone for whom water is a second home!

Power and technique combine into swimming excellence. Your shoulders roll with each stroke, muscles flexing in perfect sequence to drive maximum force through the water. Your streamlined form cuts through the waves like a knife, leaving barely a ripple in your wake. This is athletic performance at its peak - beautiful, efficient, and devastatingly effective!
success: You swim with workmanlike efficiency, arms and legs moving in steady rhythm. It's not flashy, but it works. Stroke after stroke, you propel yourself forward, slowly but surely covering the distance you need to travel.
Your swimming is competent and determined. The water provides resistance, but you have the strength to overcome it. You move forward at a steady, sustainable pace.
failure: The water seems to actively resist your efforts. Every stroke feels like you're pulling against syrup. Your legs kick with decreasing effectiveness. Despite burning effort and technical knowledge, you simply cannot make forward progress. You stay afloat, treading water, but movement eludes you.

Your swimming degrades into floundering. Arms and legs churn the water frantically, expending tremendous energy but accomplishing nothing. You're not sinking, but you're also not going anywhere. It's exhausting and futile.
criticalFailure: In one terrible moment, everything goes wrong. Maybe it's a wave you didn't see, maybe it's sudden exhaustion, maybe it's panic - but the result is the same. Your swimming fails completely. Your head goes under water before you can draw breath. You try to fight your way back to the surface, but your limbs won't cooperate. Water floods your mouth as you sink. The surface gets farther away. Your lungs scream for air. Bubbles stream upward as you plunge downward. This is drowning, and it's happening now!

Your technique collapses catastrophically. One second you're swimming, the next you're sinking. Your arms thrash uselessly. Your legs cramp or simply stop working. Panic overrides training. You go under, the water closing over your head like a grave. You struggle desperately toward what you think is up, but you're disoriented, lungs burning, terror rising. The water has claimed you!

criticalSuccess: Your body becomes a perfect swimming machine. Your arms pull with explosive power, driving you forward with each stroke. Your legs kick in rapid rhythm, adding thrust to your already impressive speed. Your breathing is perfectly controlled despite the high tempo. You're not just swimming - you're racing through the water at full land speed, barely slowed by the aquatic medium. Every muscle works in perfect harmony to generate maximum velocity!

You attack the water with athletic ferocity. Your strokes are rapid fire, one after another with barely a pause. Each pull generates tremendous forward momentum. You streamline your body to cut through the water with minimal resistance. The result is spectacular - you swim at the kind of speed normally reserved for creatures born to the water!

With phenomenal technique and raw athletic power, you transform swimming into something approaching flight. Your arms windmill with controlled fury, your legs drive like pistons, and you rocket through the water at breathtaking velocity!
success: You employ advanced swimming technique to maintain high speed through the water. Your strokes are rapid but controlled, generating enough thrust to push you forward at close to your normal running pace. It's demanding work - swimming this fast requires both skill and stamina - but you're managing it successfully.

You power through the water with determined speed. Your athletic training allows you to maintain a fast swimming pace that would exhaust most swimmers. You're covering distance rapidly, your quick stroke rate carrying you forward at impressive velocity.
Your quick swim technique is working. Through a combination of powerful strokes and efficient form, you're swimming at full speed. It's tiring, but you're making rapid progress.
failure: You attempt to employ quick swim technique, but the pace proves too demanding. Your strokes start out rapid and powerful, but within moments your form begins to break down. You can't maintain the necessary speed and have to slow to a more sustainable pace. The water has defeated your attempt at high velocity.

Despite your best efforts, you can't keep up the rapid stroke rate necessary for quick swimming. The combination of speed and technique proves beyond your current capacity. You slow down to normal swimming speed, frustrated but still moving.

You try to swim fast, but your body won't cooperate. Either your stamina isn't sufficient or your technique needs work, but the result is the same - you can't maintain quick swim speed. You revert to regular swimming pace.
criticalFailure: You commit to swimming at maximum speed, strokes coming rapid-fire, legs pumping furiously. For a few strokes it works. Then everything collapses. Your arms suddenly feel like lead. Your breathing rhythm breaks. Your legs cramp or stop responding. Before you realize what's happening, your head goes under water. You've pushed too hard, burned out too fast, and now you're sinking!

Your aggressive pursuit of speed proves catastrophic. You're swimming hard, maybe too hard. Your technique degrades under the strain. A stroke mistimes. You breathe when you should be exhaling. Water floods your mouth. Panic spikes. Suddenly you're not swimming anymore - you're floundering, sinking, drowning. Speed has betrayed you!

You overestimate your quick swim capability and push beyond your limits. Your body simply can't maintain the pace. Your arms give out mid-stroke. Your legs stop kicking. The transition from controlled swim to uncontrolled sink happens in an instant. Water closes over your head as you plunge downward!

criticalSuccess: You explode through the water like a human torpedo. This isn't normal swimming - this is aquatic athleticism at its absolute peak. Your arms pull with such power and speed that they're almost a blur. Each stroke generates tremendous forward thrust. Your legs kick with machine-like precision, adding their driving force to your momentum. Your body cuts through the water with hydrodynamic efficiency that would make an engineer weep. You're barely slowed by the aquatic medium. Water resistance? Negligible. You maintain a speed through the water that rivals your speed on land. People don't swim this fast. But you're not people - you're a trained athlete exploiting every ounce of technique and power to achieve what seems impossible. You race through the water leaving a wake like a speedboat!

This is what a master swimmer looks like when they stop holding back. You attack the water with explosive power, your entire body engaged in generating maximum velocity. Shoulders roll with perfect timing. Arms pull with devastating force. Legs drive like turbines. Your breathing is precisely controlled even at this breakneck pace. You slice through the waves with such speed that you're barely swimming - you're hydroplaning, using the water's surface to your advantage. The distance evaporates beneath your athletic prowess. You swim at the kind of speed that makes observers question whether you're fully human!
success: You employ advanced swimming technique to maintain impressive speed through the water. It's demanding work - every muscle engaged, technique pushed to its limits. But you're doing it. You're swimming fast enough that the water barely slows you down compared to land movement. It's not effortless, but it's effective.

You power through the water with determined velocity. Your stroke rate is high, your technique solid, and the combination generates significant speed. You're covering distance rapidly, swimming at a pace most people couldn't hope to match.
failure: You launch into quick swim mode with confidence, arms pulling rapidly, legs driving hard. For a few strokes it works beautifully. Then reality intervenes. The pace is simply too demanding. Your form begins to deteriorate. Your breathing rhythm breaks. Your stroke rate drops involuntarily. Within moments you realize you can't maintain this speed. You have to throttle back to normal swimming pace, the quick swim attempt defeated by your limitations.

Despite technical knowledge of quick swimming and genuine athletic effort, you simply can't maintain the velocity. The water seems to actively resist your attempts at speed. Your rapid strokes generate less thrust than they should. Your streamlined form somehow isn't enough. You slow down, forced to accept a more sustainable pace.
criticalFailure: You commit to maximum speed with absolute confidence. Your arms pull with explosive force. Your legs kick with furious rhythm. You surge forward at impressive velocity. Then, catastrophically, your body hits its limit. It happens without warning. One moment you're swimming at speed, the next your muscles simply quit. Your arms feel like dead weight. Your legs stop responding. Your carefully controlled breathing rhythm shatters. You gasp at the wrong moment and inhale water. Panic floods through you as you realize you're not swimming anymore - you're sinking. The speed that felt so exhilarating has left you exhausted and drowning!

You push for maximum swimming speed with reckless confidence. Your technique is good, your power is there, but you've overestimated your capacity. You're swimming hard - maybe too hard. The pace is unsustainable but you don't realize it until it's too late. Your form breaks down all at once. A stroke mistimes. Your breathing fails. Water floods into your mouth and nose. Suddenly everything is chaos. You're not swimming - you're thrashing, panicking, sinking. The quick swim has become a fight for survival as water closes over your head!
